values.description:
* Needs https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/39/window-icon/diff
* Nice to have https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/222/window-icon/diff

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3115933918-subticon.png)
---

Turned all the launch files into `.in` and now they're configured by cmake before being installed. The files are exactly the same, except for this line that has been added to some of them:

`<window_icon>@CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/@CATKIN_PACKAGE_SHARE_DESTINATION@/images/SubT-logo_notext_color.png</window_icon>`

This allows us to pass the full path of the installed icon to the final file. For example, on my system, the icon is populated with:

`<window_icon>/home/developer/ws/install/share/subt_ign/images/SubT-logo_notext_color.png</window_icon>`
values.title: Window icon

summary.raw:
* Needs https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/39/window-icon/diff
* Nice to have https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/222/window-icon/diff

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8ze6Mjd/images/3115933918-subticon.png)
---

Turned all the launch files into `.in` and now they're configured by cmake before being installed. The files are exactly the same, except for this line that has been added to some of them:

`<window_icon>@CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/@CATKIN_PACKAGE_SHARE_DESTINATION@/images/SubT-logo_notext_color.png</window_icon>`

This allows us to pass the full path of the installed icon to the final file. For example, on my system, the icon is populated with:

`<window_icon>/home/developer/ws/install/share/subt_ign/images/SubT-logo_notext_color.png</window_icon>`
summary.html:
• Needs https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-launch/pull-requests/39/window-icon/diff
  • Nice to have https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/222/window-icon/diff

Turned all the launch files into .in and now they're configured by cmake before being installed. The files are exactly the same, except for this line that has been added to some of them:

<window_icon>@CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX@/@CATKIN_PACKAGE_SHARE_DESTINATION@/images/SubT-logo_notext_color.png</window_icon>

This allows us to pass the full path of the installed icon to the final file. For example, on my system, the icon is populated with:

<window_icon>/home/developer/ws/install/share/subt_ign/images/SubT-logo_notext_color.png</window_icon>

values.description:
This PR significantly reduces the rate of warning messages, such as "Failed to meet update rate! Took 0.004000000000000000083", generated by the robot_localization node. The warning messages are due to the recent change in the simulation time step to 4 ms and should be harmless.  

The messages are saved in `~/.ros/logs/latest/rosout.log`. Before this PR, the size of the log files exceeded 100 MB after running the simulator for a few minutes. Now, they should remain < 1MB.

This PR also sets the `transform_timeout` parameter to be slightly longer than one simulation step to reduce the rate of warning messages, such as "Transform from X3/base_link/imu_sensor to X3 was unavailable for the time requested. Using latest instead".
values.title: Update robot_localization frequency to match simulation step time

summary.raw:
This PR significantly reduces the rate of warning messages, such as "Failed to meet update rate! Took 0.004000000000000000083", generated by the robot_localization node. The warning messages are due to the recent change in the simulation time step to 4 ms and should be harmless.  

The messages are saved in `~/.ros/logs/latest/rosout.log`. Before this PR, the size of the log files exceeded 100 MB after running the simulator for a few minutes. Now, they should remain < 1MB.

This PR also sets the `transform_timeout` parameter to be slightly longer than one simulation step to reduce the rate of warning messages, such as "Transform from X3/base_link/imu_sensor to X3 was unavailable for the time requested. Using latest instead".
summary.html:
This PR significantly reduces the rate of warning messages, such as "Failed to meet update rate! Took 0.004000000000000000083", generated by the robot_localization node. The warning messages are due to the recent change in the simulation time step to 4 ms and should be harmless.

The messages are saved in ~/.ros/logs/latest/rosout.log. Before this PR, the size of the log files exceeded 100 MB after running the simulator for a few minutes. Now, they should remain < 1MB.

This PR also sets the transform_timeout parameter to be slightly longer than one simulation step to reduce the rate of warning messages, such as "Transform from X3/base_link/imu_sensor to X3 was unavailable for the time requested. Using latest instead".

values.description:
Mercurial adds a `+`   symbol if there are uncommitted changes in the repository making the `hg id -i` to return an invalid hash to be used as docker tag.

Error here: [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim\_mirror-bionic-amd64/7/console](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim_mirror-bionic-amd64/7/console)

This PR clean that possible symbol from the hash.

Tested here: [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim\_mirror-bionic-amd64/8/console](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim_mirror-bionic-amd64/8/console)
values.title: Be sure that hg id does not return incompatible symbol with docker tag

summary.raw:
Mercurial adds a `+`   symbol if there are uncommitted changes in the repository making the `hg id -i` to return an invalid hash to be used as docker tag.

Error here: [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim\_mirror-bionic-amd64/7/console](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim_mirror-bionic-amd64/7/console)

This PR clean that possible symbol from the hash.

Tested here: [https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim\_mirror-bionic-amd64/8/console](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim_mirror-bionic-amd64/8/console)
summary.html:
Mercurial adds a + symbol if there are uncommitted changes in the repository making the hg id -i to return an invalid hash to be used as docker tag.

Error here: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim_mirror-bionic-amd64/7/console

This PR clean that possible symbol from the hash.

Tested here: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/subt-install-cloudsim_mirror-bionic-amd64/8/console

values.description: Currently the pose of any unloaded artifact is zero, which is \[-10, 0, 0\] from the artifact origin, and teams can score by reporting this pose. This PR updates the initial pose to inf to prevent scoring points for any artifacts that are not yet loaded.
values.title: Initialize artifact pose to inf

summary.raw: Currently the pose of any unloaded artifact is zero, which is \[-10, 0, 0\] from the artifact origin, and teams can score by reporting this pose. This PR updates the initial pose to inf to prevent scoring points for any artifacts that are not yet loaded.
summary.html: Currently the pose of any unloaded artifact is zero, which is [-10, 0, 0] from the artifact origin, and teams can score by reporting this pose. This PR updates the initial pose to inf to prevent scoring points for any artifacts that are not yet loaded.

gz9 .world files added for DAT generation.

A few things were updated in the SDF to the latest version - ambient lighting, max step size 0.004, levels, fuel path, and artifact\_origin.

DOT files were already in the original PR and are unchanged.

values.description:
This functionality is strictly for validation, not to be used in competition runs.

It adds the ability to relay the simulation service `/set_pose` to a ROS service. This allows for the teleportation of models from a solution docker container.
values.title: Add relay for /set_pose when ground truth is enabled

values.description:
This uses absolute comms topic and service names to allow placing controllers under a ROS namespace. I didn't know if there's a way to write a test for it, but it can be tested using the example in subt\_seed.

# To Test

Launch a practice tunnel

```
ign launch -v 4 tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

In another terminal, run subt\_seed with a namespace. Since the code in subt\_seed uses a relative name for `cmd_vel`, it needs to be remapped.

```
rosrun subt_seed subt_seed_node "X1" __ns:=/test X1/cmd_vel:=/X1/cmd_vel
```

This might address issue #143
values.title: Allow comms client under a ROS namespace

This might address issue #143

This uses absolute comms topic and service names to allow placing controllers under a ROS namespace. I didn't know if there's a way to write a test for it, but it can be tested using the example in subt_seed.

To Test

Launch a practice tunnel

ign launch -v 4 tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

In another terminal, run subt_seed with a namespace. Since the code in subt_seed uses a relative name for cmd_vel, it needs to be remapped.

rosrun subt_seed subt_seed_node "X1" __ns:=/test X1/cmd_vel:=/X1/cmd_vel

This might address issue #143

values.description:
This fixes a deadlock that occurs when `SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact` is called concurrently with `SubtRosRelay::OnMessage`. Consider two `subt_seed_node`s with robot names X1 and X2. Let's say X2 sends a message to X1. This is a call to `SubtRosRelay::OnSendTo` which sends the request to Transport and returns immediately. In the mean time, let's say X1 calls `SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact`. Since X1 is single threaded node, this call is blocking. Now, if it happens that Tranport is ready to send the message from X2 to X1, it will invoke `SubtRosRelay::OnMessage` from a separate thread. This will in turn make a service call to X1 which happens to be blocking on its service call to `SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact`. This results in a deadlock.

The solution I found is to use a lock free data structure to queue up messages when they arrive at `SubtRosRelay::OnMessage` and process them in a separate thread.

* Related PR #272

## To test

In an osrf/subt -b tunnel\_circut catkin workspace Terminal 1:

```
ign launch cloudsim_sim.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG3
```

Terminal 2:

```
ign launch cloudsim_bridge.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG3
```

In an osrf/subt\_seed workspace

Terminal 3:

```
roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1
```

Terminal 4 launch this before X1 reaches its goal \(i.e., right after launching X1\):

```
roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X2
```

**Expected Behavior:** Both robots reach their goals. But without this PR, as soon as X2 is started, both robots start reporting `Failed to call pose_from_artifact_origin service, robot may not exist, be outside staging area, or the service is not available.` As a result, they never reach their goal.
values.title: Fix deadlock between Transport thread and ROS service callbacks

summary.raw:
This fixes a deadlock that occurs when `SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact` is called concurrently with `SubtRosRelay::OnMessage`. Consider two `subt_seed_node`s with robot names X1 and X2. Let's say X2 sends a message to X1. This is a call to `SubtRosRelay::OnSendTo` which sends the request to Transport and returns immediately. In the mean time, let's say X1 calls `SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact`. Since X1 is single threaded node, this call is blocking. Now, if it happens that Tranport is ready to send the message from X2 to X1, it will invoke `SubtRosRelay::OnMessage` from a separate thread. This will in turn make a service call to X1 which happens to be blocking on its service call to `SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact`. This results in a deadlock.

The solution I found is to use a lock free data structure to queue up messages when they arrive at `SubtRosRelay::OnMessage` and process them in a separate thread.

* Related PR #272

## To test

In an osrf/subt -b tunnel\_circut catkin workspace Terminal 1:

```
ign launch cloudsim_sim.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG3
```

Terminal 2:

```
ign launch cloudsim_bridge.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG3
```

In an osrf/subt\_seed workspace

Terminal 3:

```
roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1
```

Terminal 4 launch this before X1 reaches its goal \(i.e., right after launching X1\):

```
roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X2
```

**Expected Behavior:** Both robots reach their goals. But without this PR, as soon as X2 is started, both robots start reporting `Failed to call pose_from_artifact_origin service, robot may not exist, be outside staging area, or the service is not available.` As a result, they never reach their goal.
summary.html:
This fixes a deadlock that occurs when SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact is called concurrently with SubtRosRelay::OnMessage. Consider two subt_seed_nodes with robot names X1 and X2. Let's say X2 sends a message to X1. This is a call to SubtRosRelay::OnSendTo which sends the request to Transport and returns immediately. In the mean time, let's say X1 calls SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact. Since X1 is single threaded node, this call is blocking. Now, if it happens that Tranport is ready to send the message from X2 to X1, it will invoke SubtRosRelay::OnMessage from a separate thread. This will in turn make a service call to X1 which happens to be blocking on its service call to SubtRosRelay::OnPoseFromArtifact. This results in a deadlock.

The solution I found is to use a lock free data structure to queue up messages when they arrive at SubtRosRelay::OnMessage and process them in a separate thread.

  • Related PR #272

To test

In an osrf/subt -b tunnel_circut catkin workspace Terminal 1:

ign launch cloudsim_sim.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG3

Terminal 2:

ign launch cloudsim_bridge.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_01 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG3

In an osrf/subt_seed workspace

Terminal 3:

roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1

Terminal 4 launch this before X1 reaches its goal (i.e., right after launching X1):

roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X2

Expected Behavior: Both robots reach their goals. But without this PR, as soon as X2 is started, both robots start reporting Failed to call pose_from_artifact_origin service, robot may not exist, be outside staging area, or the service is not available. As a result, they never reach their goal.

values.description:
This PR makes some improvements on the steering behavior of UGVs. Specifically, three issues are addressed:

* When a UGV is commanded to rotate in place, it sometimes stops rotating and moves straight
* The commanded angular velocity does not match the angular velocity achieved by the vehicle
* The angular velocity reported by the odometry topic is significantly different from the actual angular velocity of the vehicle

The changes that address these issues involve updates to ign-physics, ign-gazebo, the world launch files in this repo and the UGV models on Fuel

* ign-physics: New feature to send velocity commands \(ign-physics [PR #100](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1)\)
* ign-gazebo: Use the velocity command feature from ign-physics \([PR #424](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/424?w=1)\)
* launch files: Increase the `wheel_separation` parameter of the Diff drive system to align actual velocities with commanded velocities. \(This PR\)
* Fuel models: The cylinders used as collisions for the wheels on the UGV models had a rotation of `1.57079` instead of a full precision `pi/2 = 1.5707963267948966`. As a result, the contacts between the wheel and the ground were not always located in the same positions on the wheel's cylinder. Another change was to update the wheel slip parameters to match the slip behavior of the vehicles in SubT Gazebo9.

**Requires** ign-gazebo [PR #424](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/424?w=1) and ign-physics [PR #100](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1) as well as updates to the X1 and X2 models on Fuel. I have uploaded the updated models to my account on Fuel for testing. I have also created a [branch](#!/osrf/subt/branch/test_ugv_steering) that uses the models from my account.

## To test

* Build ign-physics [PR #100](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1) and ign-gazebo [PR #424](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/424?w=1)
* Checkout the `test_ugv_steering` branch and build.
* Make sure `~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/azeey/` is empty
* Run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

X2 can also be tested by changing the robotName and robotConfig arguments.

On another terminal, send a velocity command to the vehicle.

```
rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.0
angular:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.2"
```

On another terminal, check the odometry's angular velocity output

```
rostopic echo /X1/odom/twist/twist/angular/z
```

On another terminal, check the imu's angular velocity output

```
rostopic echo /X1/imu/data/angular_velocity/z
```

Another test is to have the vehicle move on a path with a constant curvature. For example, a circular path of radius= 2m at a forward velocity of 0.5 is achieved by

```
rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 0.5
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.0
angular:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.25"
```
values.title: Improved steering for UGVs

summary.raw:
This PR makes some improvements on the steering behavior of UGVs. Specifically, three issues are addressed:

* When a UGV is commanded to rotate in place, it sometimes stops rotating and moves straight
* The commanded angular velocity does not match the angular velocity achieved by the vehicle
* The angular velocity reported by the odometry topic is significantly different from the actual angular velocity of the vehicle

The changes that address these issues involve updates to ign-physics, ign-gazebo, the world launch files in this repo and the UGV models on Fuel

* ign-physics: New feature to send velocity commands \(ign-physics [PR #100](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1)\)
* ign-gazebo: Use the velocity command feature from ign-physics \([PR #424](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/424?w=1)\)
* launch files: Increase the `wheel_separation` parameter of the Diff drive system to align actual velocities with commanded velocities. \(This PR\)
* Fuel models: The cylinders used as collisions for the wheels on the UGV models had a rotation of `1.57079` instead of a full precision `pi/2 = 1.5707963267948966`. As a result, the contacts between the wheel and the ground were not always located in the same positions on the wheel's cylinder. Another change was to update the wheel slip parameters to match the slip behavior of the vehicles in SubT Gazebo9.

**Requires** ign-gazebo [PR #424](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/424?w=1) and ign-physics [PR #100](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1) as well as updates to the X1 and X2 models on Fuel. I have uploaded the updated models to my account on Fuel for testing. I have also created a [branch](#!/osrf/subt/branch/test_ugv_steering) that uses the models from my account.

## To test

* Build ign-physics [PR #100](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/100?w=1) and ign-gazebo [PR #424](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/424?w=1)
* Checkout the `test_ugv_steering` branch and build.
* Make sure `~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/azeey/` is empty
* Run

```
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```

X2 can also be tested by changing the robotName and robotConfig arguments.

On another terminal, send a velocity command to the vehicle.

```
rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.0
angular:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.2"
```

On another terminal, check the odometry's angular velocity output

```
rostopic echo /X1/odom/twist/twist/angular/z
```

On another terminal, check the imu's angular velocity output

```
rostopic echo /X1/imu/data/angular_velocity/z
```

Another test is to have the vehicle move on a path with a constant curvature. For example, a circular path of radius= 2m at a forward velocity of 0.5 is achieved by

```
rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 0.5
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.0
angular:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.25"
```
summary.html:
This PR makes some improvements on the steering behavior of UGVs. Specifically, three issues are addressed:

  • When a UGV is commanded to rotate in place, it sometimes stops rotating and moves straight
  • The commanded angular velocity does not match the angular velocity achieved by the vehicle
  • The angular velocity reported by the odometry topic is significantly different from the actual angular velocity of the vehicle

The changes that address these issues involve updates to ign-physics, ign-gazebo, the world launch files in this repo and the UGV models on Fuel

  • ign-physics: New feature to send velocity commands (ign-physics PR #100)
  • ign-gazebo: Use the velocity command feature from ign-physics (PR #424)
  • launch files: Increase the wheel_separation parameter of the Diff drive system to align actual velocities with commanded velocities. (This PR)
  • Fuel models: The cylinders used as collisions for the wheels on the UGV models had a rotation of 1.57079 instead of a full precision pi/2 = 1.5707963267948966. As a result, the contacts between the wheel and the ground were not always located in the same positions on the wheel's cylinder. Another change was to update the wheel slip parameters to match the slip behavior of the vehicles in SubT Gazebo9.

Requires ign-gazebo PR #424 and ign-physics PR #100 as well as updates to the X1 and X2 models on Fuel. I have uploaded the updated models to my account on Fuel for testing. I have also created a branch that uses the models from my account.

To test

  • Build ign-physics PR #100 and ign-gazebo PR #424
  • Checkout the test_ugv_steering branch and build.
  • Make sure ~/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/azeey/ is empty
  • Run
ign launch -v 4 competition.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

X2 can also be tested by changing the robotName and robotConfig arguments.

On another terminal, send a velocity command to the vehicle.

rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.0
angular:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.2"

On another terminal, check the odometry's angular velocity output

rostopic echo /X1/odom/twist/twist/angular/z

On another terminal, check the imu's angular velocity output

rostopic echo /X1/imu/data/angular_velocity/z

Another test is to have the vehicle move on a path with a constant curvature. For example, a circular path of radius= 2m at a forward velocity of 0.5 is achieved by

rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 0.5
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.0
angular:
  x: 0.0
  y: 0.0
  z: 0.25"

values.description:
This fixes running multiple robots using `cloudsim_sim` and `cloudsim_bridge` in catkin workspaces.

To test....

*terminal 1:* `ign launch cloudsim_sim.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG2`

*terminal 2:* `ign launch cloudsim_bridge.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG2`

*terminal 3(using subt_seed)*: `roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1`

*terminal 4(using subt_seed)*: `roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X2`


This is *not* how `cloudsim` runs, but it does allow local testing.
values.title: Fix local bridge

summary.raw:

*terminal 3(using subt_seed)*: `roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1`

summary.html:
This fixes running multiple robots using cloudsim_sim and cloudsim_bridge in catkin workspaces.

To test....

terminal 1: ign launch cloudsim_sim.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG2

terminal 2: ign launch cloudsim_bridge.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG2

terminal 3(using subt_seed): roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X1

terminal 4(using subt_seed): roslaunch subt_seed x1.launch robot_name:=X2

This is not how cloudsim runs, but it does allow local testing.

```
 #include <ignition/common/Util.hh>
          ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
```

values.description:
replaces pull request #129

Added a leak detector sensor plugin that is to be attached a logical camera sensor. It filters the sensor data to look for the a leak with the specified name.

The leak intensity calculation is taken from [srcsim](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/srcsim/src/b43622a1dbf61ef30001ec6a5d241babe37b2015/src/Task3.cc#lines-350)

‌

The plugin is currently not used by any robots so I’ve added an example world for testing. To run the demo:

```
IGN_GAZEBO_SYSTEM_PLUGIN_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH ign gazebo -v 4 leak_detector.sdf
```

and echo the `/leak` topic:

```
ign topic -e -t /leak
```

‌
values.title: Add leak detector plugin
